title: 109_hr4823
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program Act of 2006". The United States and Poland have had close diplomatic relations since 1919. Poland joined NATO in 1999 and the EU in 2004. Poland has supported US efforts against global terrorism and has collaborated on various issues such as democratization and human rights. The United States and Poland have strong diplomatic relations, with Poland joining NATO in 1999 and the EU in 2004. Both countries aim to invest in their youth to strengthen ties between societies and promote international cooperation. Poland, after receiving international assistance, is now committed to contributing its own resources towards shared goals with the United States. The United States and Poland have strong diplomatic relations, with Poland joining NATO in 1999 and the EU in 2004. Both countries aim to invest in their youth to strengthen ties between societies and promote international cooperation. Poland is committed to contributing its own resources towards shared goals with the United States. Additionally, there is a United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program established. The President, with the Secretary of State and Poland, may establish a youth exchange program called the "United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program" to promote cooperation based on common values. Eligible participants must be citizens or nationals of either country, under 19 years old, and enrolled students. The United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program allows students from both countries to study abroad for up to one academic year. Participants must be enrolled in a secondary school, accepted into an approved study abroad program, and meet additional qualifications set by the President. During the program, students will live in the host country, attend public school, and focus on academic studies with an emphasis on the host country's history, constitution, and political development. Participants in the United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program must be eligible for an internship in the host country and engage in activities determined by the President to achieve program goals. The President can use authorities from the United States Information and Educational Exchange Act of 1948 to establish and implement the program. The Secretary of State must provide an annual report to Congress on the United States-Poland Parliamentary Youth Exchange Program, detailing the implementation, number of participants, schools attended, areas of study, internships, and other activities. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for the Department of State for fiscal year 2007 is provided to carry out the youth exchange program authorized by this Act. Amounts authorized shall remain available until expended.
